concern:
I’m looking for advice on how to make a decision on majors. I am currently taking full-time PSEO courses at a private college in Minnesota, in my Junior year of HS. I am covering my generals, but soon I am going to have to make a decision so I don't waste next year on random courses that might not benefit my future. This first semester of college has been amazing, and also really anxiety provoking when I consider how fast time is passing. I can't imagine how much greater my anxiety will be when I actually have to start paying for the classes I take. 

My plan has always been to go to school for years on end and earn my VMD license. I do really enjoy working with animals and have fostered numerous cats and dogs. I even plan to get my school paid for by joining the military, the army has a vet school program. I get good grades and enjoy the biology and science classes I have taken, but recently I have been very anxious about my future. I'm beginning to question my motives. I feel like I haven't really explored other career options because it has just always been known that I will go into a veterinary career. I have heard my entire life,

“you're an animal whisperer,” 

“you wouldn't do well working with actual humans,”

“you can do anything you want in life,”

from the adults that seem to know everything there is to learn. I feel like at this point, I can't change my career path because it is just socially accepted that this is it. I would be happy to be a Vet! I know there are many who struggle to see cruelty cases every day, and there is absolutely change needed to our animal healthcare system in the US. But there are so many other options to take with my schooling and my life. Do I really want to spend my 20’s in labs and classrooms? Do I want to lose my faith in humanity when I see animals abused again and again? Can I make more of a difference if I choose to do something else with my time but donate to organizations that already make a difference? I just have this lurking feeling that getting a different job might be more realistic for the life I want. I enjoy school, but I lack any kind of social life, and I don't want it to be this way forever. I feel like I’m missing something that seems to motivate everyone else. 

I enjoy the arts and have been active in the art scene in my city. I went to a Performing arts High School and loved the environment to uplift my community. But there isn’t enough money to support a mediocre vocalist in our current media craze. I so enjoy history and would love a job as a environmental historian, or maybe an environmental chemist. Anything to study the world around me, and appreciate the natural ways of the world, and how we are so insignificant but create such wide problems. What I wouldn't do to be an anthropologist, working towards uncovering the truth behind our human development. But these fields pay so little, in a scene so wide. 

How did you decide what to do with your life? How did you decide what to major in? Is there a major that can satisfy the possibility of everything I could do? What if I get through my first veterinary med class just to puke at an incision site? Do I go for a lighter job, say, environmental preservation, with the possibility of never retiring? It's all some big scam, sure, but I have this feeling it matters so much. 

And then comes actually choosing the school to best serve my major! And does it really matter where you go? Do schools really vary so much under the same curriculum? Is it normal to be so worked up about this? I just can't help thinking this decision I make at such a young age might make me unhappy for the rest of my life. The potential for success is so great, and the likelihood of unhappiness also. Any advice is appreciated. Or maybe just thanks for reading my brain dump.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! What's on your mind today? I'm here to listen and provide a nonjudgmental space for you to share your thoughts and concerns.

I'm feeling really anxious about deciding on a major and career path, especially since I've always been steered towards veterinary medicine but am curious about other fields like the arts or environmental studies. It's overwhelming to think that this choice could shape my future happiness and social life in ways I'm not sure about yet.

It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure to make a big decision about your future, and you're also grappling with the desire to explore other interests. It's totally normal to feel overwhelmed and uncertain in this situation. Have you thought about what draws you to these other fields, or what worries you about pursuing them?

I'm drawn to fields like the arts for the creative community and sense of upliftment they provide, and to environmental studies for their focus on understanding and preserving the natural world. However, I'm worried about the financial instability and lower earning potential in these areas, which makes me anxious about longterm security and balancing my passions with practical life needs.

It sounds like you're torn between your passions and practical concerns, which is a common dilemma for many people. On one hand, you're drawn to the creative and uplifting aspects of the arts, and the meaningful work of environmental studies, but on the other hand, you're worried about the financial stability and security that may come with pursuing those fields. It's understandable to feel anxious about balancing your passions with practical needs. Have you considered exploring ways to combine your interests, or finding a career path that incorporates elements of both?

Yes, I've considered ways to combine my interests, like perhaps integrating animal welfare with environmental studies to create a career that feels more holistic and meaningful. However, I'm still anxious about whether such paths would provide the financial stability I need to avoid longterm regrets.

It sounds like you're exploring ways to align your passions with your career goals, which is a great step. The idea of combining animal welfare and environmental studies into a holistic career path sounds really interesting. However, it's understandable that you're still feeling anxious about the financial stability aspect. Have you done any research into the job prospects and earning potential in this field, or talked to anyone who works in a similar role?

I've done some initial research on job prospects in fields like environmental science, which seem to offer modest starting salaries and potential for growth in roles like conservation, but I'm concerned it might not provide the financial security I crave. I haven't yet talked to anyone in a similar role, as my anxiety has kept me from reaching out, making me feel even more uncertain about committing to this path.

It sounds like you're taking steps to gather information, but your anxiety is holding you back from reaching out to people who might have valuable insights. It's understandable to feel nervous about making a commitment without all the information you'd like to have. Have you considered starting with smaller steps, like reaching out to a career counselor or someone in your network who might know someone in the field?

I've thought about reaching out to a career counselor as a smaller step to gather more insights, but my anxiety often holds me back from initiating those conversations. It might help alleviate some of my uncertainty about combining my interests with practical career options.

It's great that you're considering reaching out to a career counselor, even if anxiety is making it difficult. Remember that career counselors are there to help you navigate these kinds of decisions, and they're likely used to working with people who are feeling anxious or uncertain. Would it help if you thought of some specific questions to ask them beforehand, so you feel more prepared going into the conversation?

client Yes, thinking of specific questions beforehand would help me feel more prepared and less overwhelmed during the conversation, as it could give me a sense of control over my uncertainties. However, I'm still anxious that even with preparation, the answers might not fully resolve my fears about career choices and financial stability.

It's understandable that even with preparation, you might still feel anxious about the unknowns surrounding your career choices and financial stability. It's important to remember that uncertainty is a natural part of the decisionmaking process, and it's okay to feel some anxiety around it. That being said, gathering as much information as possible can help you make a more informed decision. Have you considered setting a deadline for yourself to make a decision, so that you don't feel like you're stuck in limbo indefinitely?

I've considered setting a deadline for myself to make a decision, as it could help push me out of this ongoing uncertainty, but I'm anxious that it might increase my stress and lead to a choice I later regret due to incomplete exploration of my options.

It's true that setting a deadline could potentially increase stress, but it can also help you prioritize your time and energy towards making a decision. To help mitigate the risk of regret, have you thought about creating a pros and cons list for each potential career path, including factors like job satisfaction, financial stability, and personal growth?

I've thought about creating a pros and cons list for each career path, as it could help organize my thoughts on factors like job satisfaction and financial stability, but I'm anxious that it might oversimplify the emotional and longterm impacts, potentially leading to regrets if I don't fully capture my uncertainties.

That's a valid concern. While a pros and cons list can be helpful, it's important to remember that it's just one tool in your decisionmaking process. To help address your anxieties, you could consider adding a column to your list for potential emotional impacts or longterm considerations, or even creating a separate list for those factors. Have you also thought about what your gut instinct is telling you about each career path?

Yes, I've thought about my gut instinct, which leans towards pursuing something in environmental studies for its deeper sense of purpose and connection to the natural world. However, I'm anxious that following this instinct might lead to regrets if it doesn't align with the financial stability I've always associated with a veterinary career.

It sounds like you're caught between your heart and your head, which is a tough position to be in. Your gut instinct is telling you to pursue environmental studies for the deeper sense of purpose it offers, but you're worried about the financial stability that might come with that choice. Have you considered ways to mitigate the financial risks, such as exploring scholarships or grants, or considering parttime work while you're studying?

Yes, I've considered exploring scholarships and grants to help with the costs of studying environmental fields, as well as parttime work to build financial security. However, I'm still anxious that these measures might not fully alleviate the longterm financial risks, potentially leading to regrets if my career path doesn't provide the stability I've envisioned.

It's natural to feel anxious about the longterm financial implications of your career choices. While scholarships, grants, and parttime work can help, it's important to also consider the potential earning potential and job prospects in the field. Have you researched the average salaries and job growth projections for environmental careers, and compared them to those for veterinary medicine?

I've done some research on average salaries and job growth for environmental careers, which show modest starting pay with potential increases in roles like conservation, compared to the higher earning potential in veterinary medicine. However, this comparison heightens my anxiety about choosing a path that might compromise longterm financial security and lead to future regrets.

concern: Hey guys I'm a rising senior and I'm thinking about attending a HBCU, but I'm also trying to consider money in this situation as we are not the most finically well off. My family will not allow community college and transfer so I'm weighing my options here, anyone have any good tips for inexpensive colleges in Pennsylvania? They don't have to be HBCU's!

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! It's great to chat with you. Is there anything in particular you'd like to talk about today?
I'm feeling stressed about my college decisions and family pressures related to finances. I'd like to talk about how to manage this anxiety and explore some practical steps forward.

It sounds like you have a lot on your mind, with the pressures of college decisions and family expectations around finances. Let's start by exploring your feelings about these issues. What specifically about the college decisions is causing you stress?

I'm stressed about the financial aspects of choosing a college, especially with my family's expectations making it feel overwhelming. It's hard to balance what I want with what's affordable, which adds to my anxiety about making the right decision.

It can be really tough to navigate the college decision process, especially when you're trying to balance your own desires with financial constraints and family expectations. It's understandable that you're feeling anxious and overwhelmed. Have you had a chance to talk openly with your family about your concerns?

I've tried talking to my family about my college concerns, but it's been challenging because their expectations add to my stress. This makes it hard to feel supported while figuring out affordable options that align with what I want.

It's really tough when the people you turn to for support are also contributing to your stress. It sounds like you're caught between wanting to please your family and making a decision that feels right for you. Have you considered reaching out to a guidance counselor or someone else who can offer an objective perspective on your situation?

I've considered reaching out to a guidance counselor for an objective view on my college options, as I'm hoping it could help alleviate some of the financial and familyrelated stress I'm facing. However, I'm worried that it might not fully resolve the conflict between my preferences and what's practical for us financially.

It's great that you're considering reaching out to a guidance counselor for support. Remember, they can offer valuable insights and resources, but you're right that it may not solve all the issues at hand. In that case, it might also be helpful to explore ways to communicate your needs and feelings to your family, so they can better understand your perspective and support you in making a decision that works for everyone.

I've been thinking about how to communicate my needs to my family, but it's challenging because their expectations often intensify my anxiety. I'd appreciate some tips on approaching those conversations to help balance my preferences with our financial realities.

It's tough to have these conversations, especially when you're already feeling anxious. One approach could be to use I statements to express your feelings without seeming accusatory. For example, you might say something like, I feel overwhelmed when I think about college decisions because I want to make a choice that's both fulfilling for me and affordable for our family. This way, you're sharing your emotions while acknowledging the importance of your family's financial concerns.

I appreciate the suggestion of using 'I statements' to communicate with my familyit could help me express my feelings without escalating tensions. However, I'm concerned that even with this approach, balancing my college preferences with our financial constraints might still feel overwhelming.

You're right, it's a delicate balance and there might not be a perfect solution. In situations like this, it can be helpful to focus on the things you can control, such as researching financial aid options, scholarships, and parttime job opportunities. By taking actionable steps, you might feel more empowered and less overwhelmed by the situation.

I appreciate the idea of focusing on what I can control, like exploring financial aid and scholarships, as it might help me feel more in charge of my college decisions. However, I'm still worried that these steps might not fully ease the anxiety from balancing my preferences with our family's financial limitations.

It's natural to worry that these steps might not fully resolve your anxiety. However, remember that taking action, even if it doesn't solve everything, can help reduce stress and give you a sense of accomplishment. Additionally, you could try mindfulness techniques or deep breathing exercises to manage anxiety in the moment. How does that sound?

That sounds like a practical way to manage my anxiety in the moment, as I'm dealing with ongoing pressures from my college decisions. I'm willing to try mindfulness techniques to help me feel more grounded while navigating these challenges.

Great! Practicing mindfulness can be a powerful tool for managing stress and anxiety. To get started, try finding a quiet place where you won't be disturbed, and focus on your breath. You can count your inhales and exhales or simply observe the sensations of breathing. If your mind wanders, gently bring your attention back to your breath. Just a few minutes of this each day can make a big difference in your overall wellbeing.

I think incorporating mindfulness into my routine could help me handle the ongoing stress from my college decisions. I'm eager to practice it daily and see if it makes a difference in feeling more balanced with my family's expectations.

That's a fantastic plan! Consistent practice can really help you develop the habit of mindfulness and make it easier to manage stress when it arises. Remember, it's a skill that takes time to develop, so be patient with yourself and celebrate your progress along the way.

I appreciate the encouragement on building a mindfulness habit it's helpful to know that being patient with myself can lead to better stress management during tough decisions. I'll make sure to celebrate small progress as I navigate these ongoing pressures.

therapist: That's a fantastic plan! Consistent practice can really help you develop the habit of mindfulness and make it easier to manage stress when it arises. Remember, it's a skill that takes time to develop, so be patient with yourself and celebrate your progress along the way. 
client: I appreciate the encouragement on building a mindfulness habit it's helpful to know that being patient with myself can lead to better stress management during tough decisions. I'll make sure to celebrate small progress as I navigate these ongoing pressures.

concern: I graduated in December of 2023. It was one of the happiest days of my life. I was in a tough and rigorous program, where I had to meet numerous requirements, those of which were dependent on wether I would graduate or not. The stress of the uncompleted requirements hanging over my head constantly, not being able to sleep the night of my 7am-6pm clinicals, eating my emotions 24/7, along with dealing with some toxic people in a class of 11; let’s just say, I couldn’t be happier to go home. To get out of there. To never look back. That, is exactly what I’ve done. Today, I sit here in bed, and I think about, specifically, the last year and a half, the peak of my educational program. To sum things up, it almost feels like a fever dream. Like it was never real. A part of me likes that. The other half of me is frightened by that. I often think there’s something wrong with me. To believe that all of that really happened. That I was in another city, away from my family, living on my own. Instead of studying to take my boards like others in my class have, I haven’t touched the material since. Every song I hear from that time period, every reminder, takes me back, to a dark place. A place that, when it’s bed time, I dream I must eventually go back to, in order to complete my doctorate; my soul wishes that things are different this time around. In my dreams, I am always trying to escape. Always being abandoned by my family. Yearning to be any place but there. I wonder, if I could’ve avoided engaging with a certain toxic person, that things would have been different. A “friend” who weighed me down just as much as my academic stress did. Someone who’s actions spoke louder than their words. Someone I was only of use to when it came to giving advice about her multiple situationships. I tried to run from her, but she wouldn’t let me. A narcissistic, master manipulator. I wish, that my parents could feel what I felt, in my time there. My siblings see it as the door to freedom, an escape from a beautiful garden, that is my household. I see it as one of the worse times of my life. To remember that Covid-19 was my escape from the most depressing time in my life, shocks me. Packing my stuff and leaving, to never look back, for the next year and a half. Despite my experience, on December 9th, I sat proudly in that chair, not giving a care at all. The most toxic person I’ve ever met in my life, was sitting next to me during my happy time; yet again, talking about someone else. I didn’t even care. I was so happy, to just be done with it all. To say goodbye, to never look back. To not have to hold onto a friendship with any of those people anymore, even though I wanted to, because they weren’t all toxic. The darkness of my past comes creeping back when I text them or engage with them. I am no longer in contact with her, because I stood my ground. I just pray and hope, that things will be different this time around. I wish I could complete my doctorate from home, without having to leave my safe place. I still wonder, why my brain chose to react the way it did, my emotions. Was it ever real?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there, how are you feeling today? Is there anything specific youd like to talk about?
I'm feeling a bit unsettled today, with some old memories creeping back unexpectedly. I'd like to talk about ways to process those past experiences and move forward positively.

It sounds like you're having a tough day, with those old memories surfacing unexpectedly. It's good that you're reaching out to talk about ways to process them. Would you be comfortable sharing a bit more about these memories?

I'm not entirely comfortable sharing more details right now, as it still feels overwhelming. Instead, I'd like to focus on general strategies for coping with these resurfacing memories and building a sense of stability moving forward.

That's completely understandable, and it's important to respect your boundaries. We can certainly discuss some general strategies for coping with these memories without delving into specifics. One technique that might be helpful is grounding exercises, which can help bring you back to the present moment when feeling overwhelmed by memories. Have you tried any grounding techniques before?

No, I haven't tried grounding techniques before, as I've been focused on avoiding triggers from my past. I'm open to learning about them, hoping they can help me stay grounded and reduce the unease from those resurfacing memories.

Grounding techniques are a great way to help you feel more connected to the present moment, and can be especially helpful when you're feeling overwhelmed by memories or emotions. One simple technique you can try is the 5 Senses Exercise. This involves focusing on each of your five senses, one at a time, to help bring you back to the here and now. Would you like me to walk you through this exercise?

Yes, I'd like you to walk me through the 5 Senses Exercise, as I'm hoping it will help me manage the unease from those unexpected memories. I'm open to trying new techniques that can bring more stability to my daily life.

Alright, let's begin the 5 Senses Exercise. Start by finding a comfortable position, whether that's sitting or standing. Now, let's focus on your sense of sight. Look around and take in your surroundings. Notice the colors, shapes, and textures around you. What do you see?
I see the soft blue walls of my bedroom and the stack of books on my desk, with their varied colors and textures. It's helping me focus on the present and feel a bit more grounded already.

That's great to hear! Now, let's move on to your sense of hearing. Listen to the sounds around you, both near and far. Notice any background noises, like the hum of an air conditioner or the distant chatter of people outside. What do you hear?

I hear the quiet hum of the fan in my room and the distant birds chirping outside, which feels calming amidst the background noise. This is helping me stay focused on the present and reduce the unease from those resurfacing memories.

Excellent! Now let's focus on your sense of touch. Feel the sensations of your body in contact with whatever you're sitting or standing on. Notice the pressure, temperature, and texture of the surface beneath you. What do you feel?

I feel the soft fabric of my bedsheets against my skin and the firm support of the mattress beneath me, which has a slight coolness to it. This awareness of the textures and sensations is helping me stay anchored in the moment and reduce the lingering unease from those resurfacing memories.

It's wonderful to hear that you're feeling more grounded and present as we progress through this exercise. Let's continue by focusing on your sense of smell. Take a deep breath in through your nose, and notice any scents or aromas around you. What do you smell?

I smell the faint, fresh scent of laundry detergent from my clean bedsheets and a subtle hint of coffee from my morning cup nearby. This awareness of the scents is helping me feel more present and easing the unease from those unexpected memories.

It's amazing how tuning into your senses can help bring you back to the present moment and ease that unease. For the final part of this exercise, let's focus on your sense of taste. If you have anything nearby that you can safely taste, like a sip of water or a piece of gum, do so now. What do you taste?

I taste the cool, refreshing flavor of a sip of water I just took, with a slight mineral note from the glass. This awareness of the taste is helping me feel more present and further easing the unease from those resurfacing memories.

It sounds like you've done a fantastic job with the 5 Senses Exercise! By engaging each of your senses, you've successfully grounded yourself in the present moment, easing the unease from those unexpected memories. Remember, you can use this technique anytime you feel overwhelmed or need to refocus. Do you feel like this exercise is something you can incorporate into your daily routine?

Yes, I believe I can incorporate this exercise into my daily routine, as it's been helpful in managing those unexpected memories. It feels like a practical tool to build ongoing stability and keep me grounded in the present.

That's wonderful to hear! The 5 Senses Exercise is a great tool to have in your toolbox, and it's fantastic that you feel confident in using it to build ongoing stability. Remember, consistency is key, so try to practice this exercise regularly, even on days when you're feeling more grounded. This will help build the habit and make it easier to turn to when you need it most.

I appreciate the reminder about consistency I'll make a point to practice the 5 Senses Exercise daily to help maintain my sense of stability. It's reassuring to have this tool as I work through lingering unease from past experiences.

concern: I have an exam tomorrow and I’ve never had to use a live proctor program until now. It’s for college algebra and my professor allowed 1 page of notes + scratch paper. What should I expect? Tbh I’ve seen really bad reviews and the more I read the more anxious I get lmao. I don’t even have a desk to sit at that is in a private, clean space. I usually do my work on my bed so I don’t know how that’s gonna work out.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?
I'm feeling really anxious about an upcoming exam that requires a new proctoring system I'm not familiar with. It's also stressing me out because my usual study space isn't set up ideally for it.

It sounds like you're feeling anxious about this new proctoring system and worried about your study space. It's understandable to feel stressed about these changes. Would you like to talk more about the specific concerns you have with the proctoring system?
Yes, I'd like to talk more about my specific concerns with the proctoring system. It's been adding to my overall anxiety about the exam setup.

It's great that you're willing to explore your concerns further. Can you tell me more about what specifically about the proctoring system is making you anxious? Is it the unfamiliarity, or are there specific aspects of the system that worry you?

It's mainly the unfamiliarity of the proctoring system that's heightening my anxiety, as I've never used it before. Additionally, there are certain aspects of how it monitors the exam process that are adding to my overall stress.

It makes sense that the unfamiliarity and monitoring aspects of the proctoring system are contributing to your anxiety. Change can be unsettling, especially when it's related to something as important as an exam. What are some of the monitoring aspects that are particularly stressful for you?

The way the proctoring system monitors my movements and environment is particularly stressful, as it makes me feel constantly watched and judged. This adds to my overall anxiety about adapting to the exam setup.

It sounds like the constant monitoring of your movements and environment is making you feel exposed and selfconscious. This can certainly add to the pressure of taking an exam. Would it help if we brainstormed some ways to create a more comfortable study space that might ease your anxiety?

Yes, I'd appreciate brainstorming ways to make my study space more comfortable, as it could help reduce the pressure I'm feeling from the exam setup. That might make me feel more prepared and less anxious overall.
Great! Let's start by thinking about what specifically about your current study space is not ideal for the proctoring system. Is it the lighting, the background, or maybe the noise level?

My current study space isn't ideal because it's not private or clean, as I usually work on my bed instead of a desk. This setup makes me anxious about how it will hold up under the proctoring system's scrutiny.

It sounds like the lack of privacy and cleanliness in your study space is a major source of anxiety for you, especially with the added scrutiny of the proctoring system. Do you have any other spaces in your home that might be more private and conducive to a clean, organized study environment?

I don't have any other spaces in my home that are particularly private or clean for studying, as my living situation is pretty limited. This is adding to my anxiety about meeting the proctoring system's requirements.

It's understandable that the limitations of your living situation are contributing to your anxiety about meeting the proctoring system's requirements. Even though you may not have an ideal space, let's think about some small changes you could make to your current setup to make it more suitable for the exam. Would it be possible to declutter your bed and create a more organized workspace, or perhaps use a divider or curtain to create a sense of privacy?

I think I could try decluttering my bed to make it a bit more organized, though I'm not sure if I have a divider or curtain on hand. Even these small changes might help ease some of my anxiety about the proctoring system's requirements.

Decluttering your bed is a great first step! Sometimes small changes can make a big difference in how we feel. Even if you don't have a divider or curtain, is there anything else you could use to create a sense of privacy, like a large piece of fabric or a strategically placed bookshelf?

I don't think I have a large piece of fabric or a bookshelf that I can easily use for privacy right now, given my limited space. Exploring these options might still help me feel a bit less exposed and anxious during the exam.

It sounds like you're open to exploring options to create a more private and comfortable study space, even with the limitations you're facing. That's a great mindset to have. Have you considered using headphones or earplugs to block out any distracting noises during the exam?

I haven't really considered using headphones or earplugs to block out noises, as I've been focused on the visual aspects of my space. That could be a helpful way to make my setup feel more controlled and reduce some of my overall anxiety.

therapist It's great that you're open to trying out new strategies to make your study space more comfortable. Using headphones or earplugs can definitely help create a sense of control and reduce distractions. Do you think it would also be helpful to do a test run with the proctoring system before the actual exam, so you can familiarize yourself with how it works and identify any potential issues ahead of time?

Yes, I think doing a test run with the proctoring system before the exam would be really helpful to reduce my anxiety about the unfamiliar setup. It could give me a better sense of control and make me feel more prepared overall.

therapist Great! Doing a test run with the proctoring system is an excellent way to ease your anxiety and ensure a smoother experience during the actual exam. Would you like to schedule a time to do the test run, so you can have peace of mind knowing that you're wellprepared?

Yes, I'd like to schedule a time to do the test run with the proctoring system, as it could help me feel more in control ahead of the exam. This might ease some of the anxiety I'm experiencing about the unfamiliar setup.

concern:
Hi guys,

I am not sure if this is the right place to post this but I really wanted to share. I had a little win today. There’s this class that I really like and the professor and I have had this unspoken friendship all semester. I participate in class and they always smile at me but we never formally met because I was petrified to show up to office hours. The thought of making conversation and awkward silences makes me wanna crawl under a blanket and never come out.

Today, however, I pushed myself to show up. I was literally standing outside the room for 10 minutes pacing back and forth. I looked crazy but I eventually found the courage to walk in there. I ended up having a great conversation with my professor and they expressed how they were glad that I showed up. It wasn’t nearly as scary as I made it out to be in my head and, get this, I kinda want to go back some day.

Celebrating this small victory in hopes that anyone who struggles with this too will feel encouraged to take that step. 🫶

dialogue_total.statement: Hey there! Im here to listen if you have anything youd like to share. Whats been on your mind lately?

I've been struggling with social anxiety, especially around initiating conversations with people like professors. It's been tough, but I'm starting to feel more encouraged after taking some small steps forward.

That's great to hear! Taking small steps forward is a fantastic way to build confidence and overcome social anxiety. What are some of the steps you've taken so far that have helped you feel more encouraged?

I've started by mustering the courage to attend my professor's office hours despite my anxiety. This small action helped me feel more confident in initiating conversations, encouraging me to consider doing it again.
That's awesome! Attending office hours is a fantastic way to get comfortable with initiating conversations. What was it like for you to take that step? Was it as scary as you thought it would be?

It was incredibly nervewracking at first, with my anxiety making me hesitate and pace outside before going in. Ultimately, it wasn't as scary as I anticipated, as the conversation flowed well and left me feeling relieved and more confident.
Sounds like you pushed through your anxiety and came out stronger on the other side! What do you think helped you overcome your initial hesitation?

I think what helped me overcome my initial hesitation was simply deciding to push through the anxiety and take that first step, despite how overwhelming it felt. That small act of courage reminded me that facing my fears can lead to rewarding experiences and build my confidence over time.

That's a powerful insight! It's amazing how much of a difference a small act of courage can make. Now that you've had this positive experience, are there any other small steps you're considering taking to continue building your confidence and overcoming your social anxiety?

I'm considering returning to my professor's office hours for another conversation to build on this momentum, as it could help me practice initiating interactions more comfortably. Additionally, I'm thinking about joining a study group to gradually expand my social engagements and further reduce my anxiety in smaller settings.

Those are great ideas! Building on your recent success and gradually expanding your social interactions are excellent ways to continue overcoming your anxiety. Do you feel ready to take those next steps?

I feel ready to take those next steps, as my recent success has given me a boost of confidence to try again. Even though some anxiety lingers, I'm motivated to build on this progress and face those interactions headon.

concern: These last two semesters, I tend to lag and get lazy at the half way point.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How are you doing today? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about?
I'm doing alright, but I've been feeling a bit unmotivated lately. Yes, I'd like to discuss ways to stay on track during my semesters.

It sounds like you're feeling a bit stuck in a rut. That's totally normal! Let's talk about what's been going on and see if we can find some strategies that work for you. Can you tell me more about what specifically has been challenging for you in staying motivated during your semesters?
I've found that maintaining my initial drive becomes challenging around the midpoint of each semester. It's mainly about struggling to sustain that early energy and focus as things progress.

It's interesting that you've noticed this pattern of losing steam around the midpoint of each semester. It can be tough to keep up that initial momentum. Have you noticed any specific triggers or circumstances that seem to contribute to this dip in motivation?

I've noticed that around the midpoint, when coursework intensifies, it feels overwhelming and disrupts my routine. Additionally, the monotony of daily studies seems to drain my initial enthusiasm, making it hard to push forward.

So, it sounds like the increased workload and the repetitive nature of your studies are the main culprits in sapping your motivation. That's a tough combination to deal with! It's understandable that you'd feel overwhelmed and drained. Have you tried any strategies in the past to combat this midsemester slump?

I've tried setting smaller daily goals and taking short breaks to refresh, but they haven't fully prevented me from losing motivation midway. That's why I decided to seek professional help like this to explore more effective approaches.

It's great that you've already been experimenting with some strategies to keep yourself motivated! Setting smaller goals and taking breaks are definitely helpful tools. Since those haven't been quite enough, let's think about other ways to keep you engaged and energized throughout the semester. One idea might be to mix up your study routinehave you tried studying in different locations, using different methods, or even studying with a group?

I've occasionally tried studying in different locations to break the monotony, but I haven't really experimented with varying my methods or joining study groups. I'm interested in trying these out, as I hope they could help sustain my energy during the tougher parts of the semester.

That's the spirit! Mixing up your routine can be a great way to keep things fresh and avoid burnout. Why don't we brainstorm some specific ideas for how you can vary your study methods and get involved with study groups? Would you prefer to start with methods or groups?

I'd prefer to start with varying my study methods, as I'm curious how that could help me maintain focus during the more challenging parts of the semester. Then, we can move on to ideas for joining study groups to see if that adds the social element I might be missing.

Sounds like a plan! Let's start with study methods. One idea is the Pomodoro Technique, where you set a timer for 25 minutes of focused work, followed by a 5minute break. Another idea is to try using different mediums for notetaking, like drawing mind maps or creating bullet points. What do you think about these suggestions?

I think the Pomodoro Technique sounds promising because it could help me maintain focus without feeling overwhelmed during the busier parts of the semester. Varying my notetaking methods, like trying mind maps, appeals to me as it might make studying more engaging and prevent the monotony that often drains my energy.

It's great that you're receptive to these ideas! The Pomodoro Technique can be a gamechanger for maintaining focus, and mixing up your notetaking methods can definitely add some variety to your routine. Now, let's think about how you can incorporate these strategies into your daily routine. Would you prefer to start with the Pomodoro Technique or the notetaking methods?

I'd prefer to start with the Pomodoro Technique, as it seems like a straightforward way to build better focus habits during the busier periods of my semester. Once I get that down, we can then discuss how to integrate varying notetaking methods to keep my routine from becoming too monotonous.

Awesome! The Pomodoro Technique is a great place to start. Let's break it down into actionable steps. First, download a Pomodoro app on your phone or computer. Then, set the timer for 25 minutes and commit to focused work during that time. When the timer goes off, give yourself a 5minute break to recharge. Repeat this process several times throughout your study sessions. Does this sound doable for you?

Yes, implementing the Pomodoro Technique sounds completely doable for me, as it fits easily into my schedule and could help me build consistent focus without overwhelming my routine. I'm excited to try it out during the busier parts of my semester to see if it keeps my energy levels more stable.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How are you doing today? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about? I'm here to listen and support you.
I'm doing okay, but I've been feeling a bit stressed and confused lately. Yes, there is something on my mind about uncertainties in my academic path that I'd like to discuss.
It sounds like you're feeling a bit overwhelmed and uncertain about your academic path. That can be really stressful. Would you like to tell me more about what's been going on?
Yes, I'd like to share a bit more about it. I'm feeling really uncertain about my academic decisions and how they might impact my future in ways I didn't expect.

It's totally normal to feel uncertain about your academic decisions and their potential impact on your future. It can be a lot to process and think about. What specific decisions are you uncertain about, if you don't mind me asking?

I'm uncertain about decisions related to my academic credentials and how they might affect my future opportunities in the US. This uncertainty has been making me question the value of my educational choices overall.

It sounds like you're really grappling with the potential implications of your academic choices, and how they might affect your future opportunities. That's a lot of pressure to carry. Can you tell me more about why you're questioning the value of your educational choices?

I'm questioning the value of my educational choices because I've received conflicting advice that makes me doubt whether my qualifications will be recognized as I hoped. This ongoing uncertainty is leaving me feeling anxious about my future prospects in the US.

It's understandable that conflicting advice about your qualifications would leave you feeling anxious and uncertain about your future prospects. It can be really difficult to navigate those types of situations. Have you considered reaching out to a career counselor or an academic advisor for some additional guidance and clarification?

Yes, I've considered reaching out to a career counselor or academic advisor to seek more clarity. I'm hoping that additional guidance could help ease the uncertainty I've been feeling about my academic choices and their future implications.

That's a great idea! Reaching out to a career counselor or academic advisor can definitely provide some valuable insight and clarity on your situation. They can help you understand the potential implications of your academic choices, and perhaps offer some guidance on how to best navigate the uncertainty you're feeling. Have you taken any steps towards reaching out to someone for help yet?

Yes, I have taken some steps by seeking advice online and coming to you for support. This has helped a little, but I'm still feeling uncertain about how my academic choices might play out in the long run.

It sounds like you've already taken some proactive steps to address your uncertainty, which is great. However, it's understandable that you're still feeling unsure about the future. Have you considered setting up an appointment with a career counselor or academic advisor who specializes in US education and job markets? They might be able to provide more specific guidance tailored to your situation.

Yes, I've considered setting up an appointment with a career counselor or academic advisor who specializes in US education and job markets. I'm hoping this could provide the clarity I need to feel more confident about my academic choices and their potential impact on my future.

That sounds like a wise decision. A specialist in US education and job markets can offer valuable insights and guidance based on their expertise. They may also be able to provide resources and support to help you navigate your academic choices and their potential impact on your future. Do you have any concerns about reaching out to a counselor or advisor?

Yes, I have some concerns that the advice from a counselor might not fully resolve my uncertainties about how my academic choices align with future opportunities. I'm worried that even with their help, the conflicting information I've encountered could leave me still feeling unsure.

That's a valid concern, and it's important to remember that seeking advice from a counselor is just one step in the process of navigating your academic choices. It's possible that the counselor may not have all the answers, but they can certainly provide guidance and support as you work through your uncertainties. It might also be helpful to gather information from multiple sources, such as talking to other students or professionals in your field, to get a wellrounded perspective on your options.

I appreciate your suggestion to gather information from multiple sources, as I'm still dealing with ongoing uncertainties about my academic choices. I'm concerned that even with more perspectives, the conflicting advice might leave me feeling just as unsure about my future opportunities.

It's definitely a complex situation, and it's understandable that conflicting advice can make it difficult to feel confident in your decisions. However, remember that uncertainty is a natural part of life, and it's okay to not have all the answers right now. You can always make adjustments to your plans as you gain more information and experience. It might be helpful to focus on the present moment and take small steps towards your goals, rather than worrying too much about the future.

I appreciate your advice about focusing on the present and taking small steps, but it's still hard for me to shake off this underlying uncertainty about my academic path. I'll try to implement that by seeking more immediate support, hoping it eases my worries in the long run.

concern: Title basically, they haven't given me a reason why and school's a month in. They admitted that they should have given it to me a while ago, but when I ask for updates they just give me the runaround. I need the money for books and school related stuff. Who do I complain to? This is essentially theft...

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How are you doing today? Is there something on your mind that you'd like to talk about?
I'm feeling pretty stressed and anxious right now. Yes, there's something on my mind related to school finances that's been weighing on me.

It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of stress and anxiety, especially around your school finances. That can be really overwhelming. Would you feel comfortable sharing a bit more about what's been going on?

I'd feel comfortable sharing a bit more, but it's been really tough dealing with this ongoing financial uncertainty at school. It's just adding to my anxiety and making it hard to focus on other things.

It makes sense that financial uncertainty at school would add to your anxiety and make it difficult to focus on other things. It sounds like this is really impacting your overall wellbeing. Have you been able to talk to anyone else about this, or are you feeling like you're dealing with it all on your own?

I've talked to the school's therapists about this, which has been a helpful step, but I still feel like I'm handling the bulk of the emotional strain on my own. It's making it tough to manage my daily stress levels effectively.

It's great that you've reached out to the school's therapists, but I can understand how it still feels like you're carrying a heavy emotional burden. Feeling like you're handling it all on your own can be really isolating. Have you considered reaching out to friends or family members who might be able to offer additional emotional support?

I've thought about reaching out to friends or family for support, but I'm hesitant because my ongoing stress from school matters is making it hard to open up. It feels overwhelming to add that to my plate right now.

It's totally understandable that you might feel hesitant to reach out to friends or family when you're already feeling overwhelmed. It can be really difficult to open up when you're dealing with so much stress. But it's important to remember that having a support system can make a big difference in managing stress and anxiety. Would you be open to brainstorming some small steps you could take to start reaching out to others?

I'm open to brainstorming some small steps for reaching out to others, as I'm still dealing with a lot of underlying stress from my school situation. However, I'm a bit worried that it might feel overwhelming at first, given how this anxiety has been affecting me lately.

It's great that you're open to brainstorming some small steps, but I understand your concern about feeling overwhelmed. We can definitely start with small, manageable steps. Maybe we could start by identifying one or two people in your life who you feel most comfortable talking to about your stress. Who comes to mind?

I think my best friend from back home comes to mind, as she's always been a great listener during tough times. Still, I'm a little hesitant because my ongoing schoolrelated stress has me feeling quite on edge right now.

It sounds like your best friend could be a great person to reach out to for support. It's normal to feel hesitant, especially when you're already feeling on edge from schoolrelated stress. Perhaps we can brainstorm some ways to make reaching out feel less overwhelming, like starting with a text or email instead of a phone call, or setting aside a specific time to talk when you know you'll be in a calm space. How does that sound?

That sounds like a helpful approach to ease into reaching out, as I'm still feeling quite anxious about my schoolrelated stress. I'm willing to try starting with a text to my best friend, but I'll need to pick a calm time to avoid adding to my current overwhelm.

That's a great idea! Starting with a text to your best friend is a small, manageable step that can help you ease into reaching out for support. It's also a good idea to pick a calm time when you're feeling less overwhelmed, so you can approach the conversation with a clearer mind. Remember, you don't have to share everything at onceeven just sharing a little bit can help you feel less alone. Do you have a time in mind when you might send that text?

I think I could send a text this evening when I'm in a quieter moment after classes, as that might help me feel more grounded. However, I'm still feeling a bit on edge from my ongoing schoolrelated stress, so I'll need to keep it simple to avoid overwhelming myself.

That sounds like a great plan, reaching out when you're in a quieter moment can definitely help you feel more centered. Remember, it's okay to keep your text simple and focused on expressing how you're feeling and that you could use some support. You don't have to go into all the details right away. Maybe something like, Hey, I've been feeling really stressed out lately with some school stuff and could really use a friend to talk to. No pressure, but would you be up for chatting sometime soon?

That sounds like a simple and manageable way to reach out, as I'm still feeling quite stressed from my ongoing school situation. I'll try using something like that in my text this evening, keeping it brief to help ease my anxiety.

Great! Reaching out in a simple and manageable way is a good way to start. Remember, you're not alone in this, and having a supportive friend can make a big difference. You're taking a brave step by reaching out, and that's something to be proud of.

I appreciate your encouragement, as it's helping me feel a bit more motivated despite the ongoing stress from my school situation. I'll make sure to keep the text simple and reach out to my best friend this evening when things are calmer.

concern:
Hi. This post is just gonna be me venting/asking for thoughts? 

I started college at 17 and now I am graduating with a Biology degree. I graduate in 2 months. College really has not been fun for me. I've struggled a lot with my grades, mental health, friends, financially, etc. I have not had a car throughout college. Most of my days have been spent on campus and not being able to go out. Most of the "fun" times I have had in college involved substance abuse. I had a friend group in my junior year and we would just get drunk and go to parties. I got assaulted twice at a party. After that, I distanced myself from the group and stopped going out. Now, its my second semester of my senior year. All of senior year, I have not had any friends and spent September-now alone. My best friend lives a few hours away and goes to another school and we talk everyday. However, I dont have anyone on campus to hang out with. I am looking forward to my life after college. I will be financially independent, have a car, an apartment and have the freedom I have been craving. I wont have to rely on my parents financially and can really be an adult. I already have a few companies ready to hire me. I just want it to be April so badly so I can graduate and move on to the next chapter of my life. I feel depressed when I have to go to class still and do assignments. I know I sound whiny and dumb. But I am so deeply burnt out from school and everything I've gone through. I am still passing all my classes and managing fine. But everyday feels the same and I just have urges to self destruct. I want to go back to substance abuse to cope with my feelings. But I know if I do that, my grades will suffer, and I dont want to fuck up when Im so close to graduating. I dont really feel excited about graduating and it doesnt feel real. I keep feeling like something will randomly happen that stops me from graduating. I wish I could just calm down and ride out these last 2 months and be happy about this huge accomplishment. My parents are so happy and proud of me. I dont understand whats wrong with me and why I cant just be happy for myself. I also feel like I am not ready to be an actual adult because I have not had that many real-life experiences.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How are you doing today? Im here to listen if theres anything youd like to share.
I'm not doing great today I've been feeling pretty burnt out and down about school. I'd like to talk about some of the challenges I'm facing as I wrap up my time here.

That sounds like a tough spot to be in, and I'm glad you're reaching out. Burnout can really wear on you, and it's especially hard when you're trying to finish up school. Would you like to tell me more about the challenges you're dealing with?

Yes, I'd like to share more about the burnout I'm experiencing, as it's making it really tough to stay motivated in my final months. I've been feeling isolated and overwhelmed, which is amplifying my struggles with daily routines.

It's understandable that burnout is making it hard to stay motivated, especially with the added feelings of isolation and overwhelm. Those are heavy emotions to carry. When you say you're struggling with daily routines, what specific tasks or activities are you finding most challenging?

Attending classes and completing assignments are the most challenging tasks for me right now, as they feel overwhelmingly repetitive and draining. My isolation on campus makes it even harder to find the motivation to push through them.

It's clear that these tasks are taking a lot out of you, and the isolation isn't helping either. I can see how the combination of burnout and loneliness would make it really tough to keep up with your coursework. Have you thought about any potential changes that could help alleviate some of this stress, even if just a little bit?

I've thought about making small changes like reaching out to my offcampus best friend more often for support, which helps a bit with the isolation. I'm also considering focusing on my postgraduation plans to remind myself that this burnout is temporary and will end soon.

Those are both excellent ideas! Maintaining social connections, even if they're not on campus, can be a great source of support during tough times. And focusing on your postgraduation plans is a fantastic way to remind yourself that this is just a temporary phase. It sounds like you're already taking steps to tackle the isolation and burnout. Have you thought about any strategies to help with the actual coursework, like breaking assignments into smaller tasks or setting a daily routine for class attendance?

I've considered breaking assignments into smaller, more manageable tasks to make them less overwhelming, but it's still tough to start due to my ongoing burnout. Setting a daily routine for class attendance sounds helpful, yet I worry it might not fully address the isolation that's draining my motivation right now.

It's good that you're thinking about ways to manage the workload, but it's also important to acknowledge that burnout is a significant factor. Maybe we can approach this from a different angle instead of focusing solely on the coursework, let's brainstorm some ways to combat the burnout and isolation that are at the root of the problem. Would you be open to exploring some selfcare strategies that could help you feel more energized and connected?

Yes, I'm open to exploring selfcare strategies that could help me feel more energized and connected, as I'm eager to find ways to ease my burnout. However, I'm concerned that without addressing the isolation on campus, these strategies might not fully counteract the daily drain I'm experiencing.

That's a valid concern, and you're right that selfcare strategies alone might not fully solve the issue. Perhaps we can think about ways to combine selfcare with efforts to build connections on campus. For example, you could join a study group or attend campus events that align with your interests. That way, you're not only taking care of yourself but also creating opportunities to connect with others and break out of that isolating bubble. Does that sound like something you'd be willing to try?

Yes, I'm willing to try joining a study group or attending campus events to build connections, as I'm hoping it could help alleviate some of my isolation. However, I'm concerned that my ongoing burnout might make it challenging to fully engage and benefit from these activities right now.

therapist: Hi there! How are you doing today? Im here to listen if theres anything youd like to share.
client: I'm not doing great today I've been feeling pretty burnt out and down about school. I'd like to talk about some of the challenges I'm facing as I wrap up my time here.
therapist: That sounds like a tough spot to be in, and I'm glad you're reaching out. Burnout can really wear on you, and it's especially hard when you're trying to finish up school. Would you like to tell me more about the challenges you're dealing with?
client: Yes, I'd like to share more about the burnout I'm experiencing, as it's making it really tough to stay motivated in my final months. I've been feeling isolated and overwhelmed, which is amplifying my struggles with daily routines.
therapist: It's understandable that burnout is making it hard to stay motivated, especially with the added feelings of isolation and overwhelm. Those are heavy emotions to carry. When you say you're struggling with daily routines, what specific tasks or activities are you finding most challenging?
client: Attending classes and completing assignments are the most challenging tasks for me right now, as they feel overwhelmingly repetitive and draining. My isolation on campus makes it even harder to find the motivation to push through them.
therapist: It's clear that these tasks are taking a lot out of you, and the isolation isn't helping either. I can see how the combination of burnout and loneliness would make it really tough to keep up with your coursework. Have you thought about any potential changes that could help alleviate some of this stress, even if just a little bit?
client: I've thought about making small changes like reaching out to my offcampus best friend more often for support, which helps a bit with the isolation. I'm also considering focusing on my postgraduation plans to remind myself that this burnout is temporary and will end soon.
therapist: Those are both excellent ideas! Maintaining social connections, even if they're not on campus, can be a great source of support during tough times. And focusing on your postgraduation plans is a fantastic way to remind yourself that this is just a temporary phase. It sounds like you're already taking steps to tackle the isolation and burnout. Have you thought about any strategies to help with the actual coursework, like breaking assignments into smaller tasks or setting a daily routine for class attendance?
client: I've considered breaking assignments into smaller, more manageable tasks to make them less overwhelming, but it's still tough to start due to my ongoing burnout. Setting a daily routine for class attendance sounds helpful, yet I worry it might not fully address the isolation that's draining my motivation right now.
therapist: It's good that you're thinking about ways to manage the workload, but it's also important to acknowledge that burnout is a significant factor. Maybe we can approach this from a different angle instead of focusing solely on the coursework, let's brainstorm some ways to combat the burnout and isolation that are at the root of the problem. Would you be open to exploring some selfcare strategies that could help you feel more energized and connected?
client: Yes, I'm open to exploring selfcare strategies that could help me feel more energized and connected, as I'm eager to find ways to ease my burnout. However, I'm concerned that without addressing the isolation on campus, these strategies might not fully counteract the daily drain I'm experiencing.
therapist: That's a valid concern, and you're right that selfcare strategies alone might not fully solve the issue. Perhaps we can think about ways to combine selfcare with efforts to build connections on campus. For example, you could join a study group or attend campus events that align with your interests. That way, you're not only taking care of yourself but also creating opportunities to connect with others and break out of that isolating bubble. Does that sound like something you'd be willing to try?
client: Yes, I'm willing to try joining a study group or attending campus events to build connections, as I'm hoping it could help alleviate some of my isolation. However, I'm concerned that my ongoing burnout might make it challenging to fully engage and benefit from these activities right now.

concern:
My friend F(17) and I F (16) have been best friends since kindergarten and stuck like glue together k-7th grade. We had a falling out and both made new friends. I’m in high school now and about to go to college. We both love the same school and are planning on majoring in the same thing (I know it’s crazy how life works). Our school isn’t close to home, it’s a few hours away and I’m struggling on deciding if I want to room with her or find someone else. She is SET on rooming with me. We are still pretty close friends but not like we used to be. My hesitation is the fact that she hangs out with people I don’t align with. She smokes, parties, and doesn’t exactly prioritize school and kind of relies on me in this one class we have together. I just don’t know if i want to live with her through college but I’m also nervous I’ll regret it. She’s also a great study buddy and i love her. Please help! Should I room with my kindergarten best friend?

UPDATE: 
She really pissed me off this morning and I told her. “I can’t live with you in college” her response was I don’t really care anymore. I want to live with someone who “has fun”
Kinda hurtful because I’m not a boring person. I go to parties lol and I hangout with my friends but not until my work is done. She says she wants to be on the same floor as me but I don’t even want to do that. I also angrily mentioned her smoking and she said “yeah then you definitely shouldn’t live with me”. YALL SAVED ME. I’M FREEEE

EDIT: YOU GUYS ARE AWESOME!! THANK YOU FOR THE ADVICE

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome, I'm here to listen and help you explore your thoughts and feelings. Is there something specific you'd like to talk about today?

Thanks for welcoming me. I'd like to talk about navigating a friendship that's changed over time and how it's influencing my choices for college living arrangements. I'm feeling a mix of relief and uncertainty after a recent disagreement with her.

It sounds like you're going through a complicated time with this friendship, and that it's having a significant impact on your future plans. Change can be difficult, and it's normal to feel both relief and uncertainty. Can you tell me more about the disagreement and how it's affecting your decisionmaking process?

I recently had a heated argument with my friend about our differing priorities, which led me to firmly decide against rooming together in college. This has left me feeling relieved about setting boundaries but uncertain about how it might affect our friendship moving forward and my overall college experience.

It takes courage to set boundaries, especially with close friends. You're being proactive about your college experience, which is admirable. Your feelings of relief and uncertainty are valid. It's important to remember that friendships can evolve and change, and it's okay if you both have different priorities. Have you considered having an open conversation with your friend about how you're feeling and your decision not to room together?

Yes, I've already had a conversation with her about my decision not to room together, which helped clarify my boundaries but has left me uncertain about our friendship's future. I'm still processing how this might affect my college experience overall, especially with our differing priorities.

It's natural to feel uncertain about how this change will impact your college experience. It's great that you were able to communicate your boundaries to your friend, even if it was difficult. As you process this situation, it might help to think about the other aspects of college life that you're excited about and how you can create a supportive living environment for yourself. What are some other things you're looking forward to in college, beyond living arrangements?

I'm really excited about exploring new academic opportunities and joining clubs related to my major, as they align with my priorities and help me build a more focused college experience. Additionally, I'm looking forward to meeting new people who share similar values, which might help me create a supportive living and social environment without the uncertainties of old friendships.

It's fantastic that you're focusing on the exciting opportunities ahead of you, like academic exploration and connecting with likeminded individuals. Embracing these new experiences will not only help you grow academically, but also build a strong support system. Remember, change can be scary, but it can also lead to personal growth and new friendships.

I appreciate your reminder that change can lead to personal growth, and I'm trying to embrace that by focusing on building new connections. However, I'm still feeling a bit uneasy about how my evolving friendships might shape my overall college experience and sense of belonging.

concern: I don’t need straight A’s in all my courses and I have a 3.95 GPA currently. I’m enrolled for 21 credit hours currently but want to add one more class so I don’t need to take two classes over the summer to graduate. I’ve taken 18 and 20 credit hours the past two semesters and have been successful. Also the class I want to add would be online asynchronous so I could just do it whenever I wanted. Just wondering if anyone had success with this before?

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! Is there something on your mind that you'd like to talk about? I'm here to listen and support you.
Yes, I've been feeling a bit overwhelmed with decisions about my course schedule and whether I can handle more. I'd like to discuss ways to manage my academic load while staying on track.

It sounds like you're feeling a bit weighed down by the choices you need to make about your course schedule. Balancing academic demands can be tough, but I'm here to help you explore your options and find ways to manage your workload effectively. What specifically are you worried about when it comes to handling more?

I'm worried about potentially overcommitting myself and how that might affect my overall wellbeing and ability to perform well. Even though I've handled heavy loads before, adding more feels risky in terms of maintaining my balance and mental health.

Your concern about maintaining a healthy balance is absolutely valid. It's important to consider your wellbeing when making these decisions. It sounds like you've managed heavy loads before, which is a testament to your resilience. Let's talk through some strategies that might help you navigate this situation without overcommitting yourself. Would you like to start by discussing your current commitments and how adding more might impact them?

Yes, I'd like to discuss my current commitments to better understand how adding more could affect my overall balance. I'm concerned that it might tip the scales and impact my mental health, even though I've managed heavy loads before.

Absolutely, it's important to take a step back and assess the bigger picture. Could you walk me through your current commitments, including academic, extracurricular, and personal responsibilities? This will help us get a better sense of how adding more courses might fit into the equation.

client Sure, I'm currently handling a full course load of about 21 credit hours, along with some extracurricular activities and personal responsibilities like parttime work and family time. I'm worried that adding another class might disrupt my current balance and strain my mental health, even though I've managed heavy loads in the past.

That's a lot on your plate already! With 21 credit hours, extracurriculars, work, and family time, it's understandable to be concerned about adding more. You mentioned that you've managed heavy loads beforewhat strategies did you use then to maintain your balance and mental health?

In the past, I relied on strong time management techniques, like prioritizing tasks and scheduling regular breaks to prevent burnout. I'm considering if those strategies would still hold up now, given my concerns about maintaining my mental health with an even heavier load.

It's great that you've already developed some effective time management techniques. While they might still be helpful, it's important to consider the potential impact on your mental health with an increased workload. Perhaps we can brainstorm some additional strategies that could help you manage the added stress, while also maintaining your current balance. Would you be open to exploring some ideas together?

Yes, I'm definitely open to exploring some ideas together to help me manage this potential increase in my workload. I'm hoping we can find strategies that prioritize my mental health and prevent any further imbalance in my daily routine.

therapist Let's start by discussing some potential strategies that could help you manage the increased workload while prioritizing your mental health

1. Reassessing priorities Consider if there are any current commitments that you can scale back on or delegate to others, allowing you to free up some time and energy for the additional course.
2. Implementing selfcare routines Make sure to schedule regular time for activities that help you relax and recharge, such as exercise, meditation, or spending time with friends.
3. Utilizing campus resources Look into academic support services, counseling, or study groups that can provide additional assistance and help you manage stress.
4. Setting realistic expectations Be honest with yourself about what you can realistically achieve and be willing to adjust your goals if necessary.

Which of these strategies do you think might be the most helpful for you?

I think implementing selfcare routines and setting realistic expectations would be the most helpful strategies for me, as they directly support my mental health and help me avoid overcommitting. Reassessing priorities might also be useful to ensure I maintain a balanced routine amidst my academic demands.

therapist It's great to hear that you're prioritizing selfcare and setting realistic expectations. Here are some tips on how to effectively implement these strategies

1. Selfcare routines

 Schedule selfcare activities in your calendar and treat them as nonnegotiable appointments.
 Experiment with different activities to find what works best for you, such as exercise, meditation, journaling, or spending time in nature.
 Make sure to get enough sleep, as it's crucial for maintaining mental health and cognitive function.

2. Setting realistic expectations

 Break down your goals into smaller, more manageable tasks.
 Be kind to yourself and avoid negative selftalk if you don't meet your expectations.
 Regularly check in with yourself to see if your expectations are still realistic and adjust them if necessary.

By consistently implementing these strategies, you'll be better equipped to handle the increased workload while maintaining your mental health and overall balance.

I appreciate these tips on selfcare routines and setting realistic expectations, as they align with my goal of maintaining mental health amid my academic pressures. I'm eager to try incorporating them into my routine to ensure I don't overcommit and disrupt my overall balance.
